column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Diy_coref|
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Diy_coref_re|BT_webanno.custom.Diy_coref

#Text=[0006] The jukebox devices 16 (sometimes referred to as simply "jukeboxes" herein) are operable to communicate with the central server 12 through a communications network 14, such as, for example, the Internet.
#Text=The jukeboxes 16 periodically communicate with the server 12 in order to provide information to the server 12 regarding the specific songs that have been played on the jukebox.
#Text=The central server then uses this information in order to determine the appropriate royalties and/or other payments that are owed for songs played on each jukebox.

#Text=Thus, one significant advantage of this new generation of jukeboxes is that the sound reproduction and/or other applicable music rights can be adhered to in a more accurate and reliable manner, thereby assuring the proper royalties are paid to the artists or music owners.

#Text=The central server 12 can also provide new songs to the jukebox 16 in order to assure that the appropriate or most popular songs are maintained on the jukebox based on the specific customers at that location.

#Text=Thus, the songs available on each jukebox can be customized through communication with the central server in order to provide the songs and/or types of music that customers generally request at each jukebox location.
#Text=As described in the above-referenced U.S.
#Text=Pat.

#Text=No. 6,308,204, the central server can also advantageously be used to update the operating software on the jukeboxes in order to, for example, change the operation of the jukebox, such as to provide new or improved features.

#Text=Thus, another significant advantage of this new generation of jukeboxes is that the songs (or other audio and/or visual content), and the operation of the jukebox itself can be remotely changed as desired without the need to have someone (such as a routeman) personally service the jukebox.
#Text=Instead, such updates can be done using the central server 12.

#Text=[0007] As indicated above, the jukebox devices 16 each include a mass storage device, such as a hard drive, which stores the songs and associated video/graphics data (if any), as well as any other desired graphical information for reproduction on the jukebox.
#Text=The mass storage device of the jukebox typically has limited storage capacity relative to the storage device of the central server 12.
#Text=As a result, only a fraction of the songs stored on the central server are typically stored on the mass storage device of the jukebox at any one time.

#Text=There may be other reasons as well, such as for security of the data or limited room in the jukebox itself, for having limited storage capacity on the jukebox and/or limiting the number of songs stored thereon.
#Text=For example, physical space may be limited on wall-mount jukeboxes or the like, which are designed to be small in size as compared to free-standing models.

#Text=As explained above, the songs on the jukebox can be changed through communication with the central server, but typically any one jukebox only stores a relatively small subset of the complete library of songs maintained by the central server at any one time.
#Text=[0008] In order to maximize the revenue that a jukebox generates, it is important to make the most desired songs available on the jukebox over time.
#Text=If customers cannot find songs they like on the jukebox, usage of the jukebox (and the revenue generated thereby) will dramatically decrease.
#Text=On the other hand, it is impossible to predict in advance exactly what a customer at any particular location will desire to play on the jukebox.
#Text=In fact, there are likely many instances where a customer would have selected a song that exists on the central server but is not currently present on the jukebox.
#Text=As a result, the jukebox may not be enjoyed and used to its fullest extent.

#Text=In order to address this problem and increase revenue, jukebox systems have in the past provided a feature which enables the user to search for songs on the central server from the jukebox and request an immediate download of a desired song from the central server to the jukebox for an additional fee.

#Text=This feature enables the user to play any song in the master library of songs maintained by the central server using the jukebox, regardless of whether or not the specific song is presently stored in the mass storage of the jukebox itself.
#Text=Thus, the user can first look for desired songs on the local storage of the jukebox and then, if desired, search further on the central server for desired songs.

#Text=The jukebox device typically charges an additional fee (such as five credits instead on one credit) for an immediate download and play of a song from the central server as opposed to a standard play directly from the jukebox's local storage.
#Text=[0009] One problem, however, with the immediate downloading feature is that it is desirable to have an immediate and high speed connection with the central server to implement.
#Text=In addition, the central server and network must be prepared for and capable of handling such requests in a reliable and efficient manner for the feature to properly operate.
#Text=These requirements cannot always be met and, as a result, implementation of this feature has been limited.
#Text=For example, many locations that have jukeboxes do not have high speed connections (such as DSL) and instead use dial-up modem connections.
#Text=Jukeboxes which rely on dial-up connections generally are only designed to communicate with the server periodically and do not allow the user to immediately download a song.
#Text=They have, however, enabled a user to vote for a song to be downloaded at a later time when the dial-up connection is made.
#Text=This, of course, is not as satisfying to the user as being able to immediately download a song.
#Text=Other problems can arise in connection with this download feature if the network or server is not currently available for the download, due to traffic, malfunctions or the like.
#Text=[0010] For most users, a relationship with a jukebox extends only as far as a choice of songs to play.
#Text=Casual users may find it difficult to make selections rapidly and/or to locate specific songs.
#Text=Regular users, however, frequently choose the same songs, and they may become frustrated with always having to make the same selections.
#Text=Both problems may result in a loss of revenue from intimidation, frustration, etc.
